title: 108_s1680
content: The Act may be cited as the "Defense Production Act Reauthorization of 2003" and reauthorizes the Defense Production Act of 1950. The Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to extend certain provisions until September 30, 2008. The President is authorized to address resource shortfalls for radiation-hardened electronics under the Act. The Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to extend provisions until September 30, 2008, allowing the President to address resource shortfalls for radiation-hardened electronics without exceeding $200,000,000. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report within 6 months detailing the domestic industrial base, Department of Defense requirements, intentions, and plans for radiation-hardened electronics. The Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to extend provisions for radiation-hardened electronics until September 30, 2008, with a budget limit of $200,000,000. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report within 6 months detailing the domestic industrial base and Department of Defense requirements for radiation-hardened electronics. The Act aims to expand the availability of radiation-hardened electronics beyond existing contractual arrangements. SEC. 4 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to clarify the President's authority to obtain information for industry studies on the US industrial base. Section 702 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 is amended to define "critical infrastructure" and include it in the scope of national security. Additionally, there is a report requirement on contracting with minority- and women-owned businesses. The Secretary of Defense must submit a report to Congress within a year of the enactment of the Act on contracts with minority- and women-owned businesses under the Defense Production Act of 1950, detailing the types of goods and services obtained and the dollar amounts of such contracts. The Secretary of Defense must report to Congress on contracts with minority- and women-owned businesses under the Defense Production Act of 1950, including dollar amounts, ethnicity of owners, barriers in the contracting process, and recommendations for increasing opportunities and removing barriers. Definitions for "women-owned business" and "minority-owned business" are provided. The Secretary of Commerce is required to report on the impact of offsets on domestic contractors and lower-tier subcontractors as part of the annual report under the Defense Production Act of 1950. This includes detailing foreign contracts involving domestic contractors using offsets, industrial participation agreements, or similar arrangements over a 5-year period. The report will also calculate the values of these contracts and arrangements. The Secretary of Commerce must report on the impact of international sales of US defense products and related agreements on domestic prime contractors and lower-tier subcontractors over a 5-year period. The Department will utilize internal documents for data analysis, and non-Federal entities will only be required to provide information if necessary. The Secretary will request information from non-Federal entities that is already available in their existing data systems. The information can be provided in the same format as submitted to foreign governments for offset arrangements. A report must be submitted to Congress within 8 months of the Act's enactment, detailing the findings from the examination conducted. Copies of the report will also be sent to the United States. The report prepared under paragraph (1) will be submitted to the United States Trade Representative and an interagency team established under the Defense Production Act Amendments of 1992. The President will designate a chairman of an interagency team to consult with foreign nations on limiting adverse effects of offsets in defense procurement without harming the economy or defense industrial base. The President will direct an interagency team to meet quarterly and submit an annual report to Congress on consultations and meetings regarding defense production and preparedness. The team will also provide recommendations for modifications to existing or proposed memorandums of understanding. The President will direct an interagency team to meet quarterly and submit an annual report to Congress on consultations and meetings regarding defense production and preparedness, including any existing or proposed memorandum of understanding between the United States and foreign countries related to defense equipment or procurement.
